description: An introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity; introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility, and the cell cycle.
name: CELL. BIOL. & BIOCHEM.

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity, introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility.

Students found this course to contain a lot of information. The textbook was much more detailed than the lectures. Some students felt that they learned a lot, but some students also wished topics were connected more efficiently. Students who took BIOL121 prior to this course found BIOL202 to be very similar to material learned in BIOL121.

Students gave varied feedback for Professor Guo. While some students commented that Professor Guo was a "good lecturer," "very approachable," and "extremely knowledgeable," many students complained about Professor Guo’s time tangential lecturing. In regard to his PowerPoint presentations, many students preferred Professor Guo’s "slower pace" and a greater focus on general concepts as opposed to details. However, a few students that Professor Guo could have put more content on his slides.

Prerequisites for this course include BIOL 101 and 102, or Biol 121. Strong high school background in chemistry or CHEM 102 is recommended. Students stated that exams are very detail-oriented as opposed to concept-oriented to such an extent that some students found that the exams "did not always correlate with what we were taught." A few students felt that their grade "in this course in no way adequately reflects the understanding of the material I have gained and demonstrated" due to the exams' focus on specific details.

This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity, introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility.

Students found this course to contain a lot of information. The textbook was much more detailed than the lectures. Some students felt that they learned a lot, but some students also wished topics were connected more efficiently. Students who took BIOL121 prior to this course found BIOL202 to be very similar to material learned in BIOL121.

Students gave mixed feedback for Prof. Gregory. Some students lauded Prof. Gregory as "outstanding" and "extremely knowledgeable." Other students complained that Professor Gregory was not very approachable because he was very uptight and rather harsh on re-grade policies. Some students complained about the fast pace of his very detailed PowerPoint presentations that include a lot of unfamiliar information. However, other students found that his Professor Gregory’s annotations demonstrated the effort that went into designing "clear lectures that emphasized information that was most important."

Prerequisites for this course include BIOL 101 and 102, or Biol 121. Strong high school background in chemistry or CHEM 102 is recommended. Students stated that exams are very detail-oriented as opposed to concept-oriented to such an extent that some students found that the exams "did not always correlate with what we were taught." A few students felt that their grade "in this course in no way adequately reflects the understanding of the material I have gained and demonstrated" due to the exams' focus on specific details.
